Characters/Pairings: Miria, Clare, Teresa
Warnings: Implied spoilers, minor gore 
Summary: Even in Shonen series with girls, best friends have to end up fighting in the end. Post chapte-100, after the destruction of the Organisation and another fight beween Priscilla and Clare. References Clare and Miria's fight in the Slashers arc, when Clare passed out and dreamed of Teresa.




 

Miria drew closer to Clare’s back. Pieces of Deneve, Tabitha and Dietrich lay along their path, with the bodies of the last Abyss Feeders. Orsay lolled against his throne. All over the fortress, warriors hauled themselves from rubble where the wind kept screaming. 

 Clare moved like a falling stone. Behind her, Helen stared at a piece of Deneve’s head, without hands to hold it. Galatea stood over her, breathing like a horse. Miria walked every step with head high and lips still, tears bleaching the white of her cheeks. Clare slammed Orsay’s head into his throne’s seat.

 “Raki. Where?”

 “Uhh...the coast, yesterday. Ship for the mainland. Incredible results; he’ll spawn the ultimate weapon. Except Priscilla–but, for humanity, you must kill her. She’s still in the dungeons; your last task is to kill her, or die trying–”

 Clare smashed Orsay’s head down again, wetly, and span to face Miria.

 “Easy, girl. They’ll have taken the boy on side roads; we leave now and we can find him–” Clare was not looking at her.

 “She’s here. Raki will be alright. You saw her beat me without one blow–she walked away. Again. I can’t just hope; I have to kill that monster. Now.”

   Her eyes were roaring, their likenesses in Miria’s memory mocking and faint. The Phantom’s own eyes were half-closed, as if by weight.

 “I lost the one I cared the most for, Clare, and I swore if I lost comrades, I would never abandon them.” The dead looked out of her at Clare. “He’s the one you promised to save. I’m never going to let you go.”

 For a second Clare, did not advance, but her hand was on her sword, and the silver fire rising.

 “You might think I owe you everything, but I really don’t. It was all from Teresa, even what I have with Raki. He’ll forgive me, I know it...” Clare’s face appeared as calm and stark as the principle of revenge. “You think because it’s you, I’ll show any mercy?”

 “No. Joke? Ha...ha...ha” Helen’s whisper was only heard by Galatea.

 “Really didn’t see this coming, kid?” The nun watched the drifting hands, “They’ve crossed a limit, inside their own heads. But neither one of them are wrong. And, dear oh dear, both stronger than m–”

 Miria was gone, Clare’s cheek had burst. She turned, sword up. Stared at the lattice cut in Miria’s face, her eyes and their shocking cold–she was gone and the force of their bodies rang.


*    *     *

 With every skill they held, or perhaps nothing but passion and limb-memory, the dark warriors flew over the ruins. Feet light as clouds, then twisting in the dust as the wall of steel thunder poured through. Their faces burned white, without tears.

 Miria had the stronger yoki; even with her own released, Clare read it clearly. Miria’s sword bounced back to smash a pillar; Clare’s fell towards the place she would be, but she was through it, swinging at Clare’s face, leaping above the quicksword to strike at Clare’s head. She was taking cuts, if Miria had charged she’d have been shredded, but Clare was tiring faster.  

 Sensing a burst of yoki, Clare twisted aside, sword weaving a rainstorm; Miria rolled beneath, firing a brutal kick into Clare’s instep. Her face was monstrous, yoma-powered strikes batting the rapid dance of the quicksword aside–Clare had to block with full strength on the left, her back was open–

 Clare wrenched her sword about, as Miria jumped back against a pillar and vanished. Clare’s side exploded. She couldn’t see Miria, she could sense the yoma, coming–

 Red dirt burst on Clare’s face. She threw the quicksword around herself, until she slumped down, choking. A second wound had almost cut half-way through her chest.

 “You always had the techniques,” Miria was saying, “But your body cripples them. I can’t read yoma like you do, but I’ve fought for so long, I read nearly as much in your human soul. I know you, Clare–no one else better than you.”

 “Nine years...and you think wounds make me give up? The pain doesn’t compare.”

 “No, you won’t give up. You never do...”

 Yoma power blasted from Clare’s body; batting Miria’s sword aside as she leapt up–with control that made Miria catch her breath, she switched to a yoki-sensing level, dodging a phantom attack. Dodging another and swinging everything around like arc lightning.

  Dust billowed from their feet, as they staggered back. Clare had another deep wound, but Miria’s shoulder was carved away, her arm dead. Miria smiled faintly, as Clare turned, shining with the power of a death-or-victory strike.

 “No, you’re going to live,” Miria’s whisper was steel-clear, “live for that boy’s life, Clare....”

 Clare snarled, dashed forward, tears shining in the roar of Yoki–

 “You can’t die, Clare. You’ll hear him over the ocean ‘CLARE COME BACK!’”

 Clare stopped. Miria’s breath heaved in her ear, her Yoki was gone, her sword lying beside the arm Miria had silently cut away. Clare staggered back to the floor, breathing without air.

 “Yoki synchronisation. I could only ever have learnt it for you. You were...really, the strongest Warrior living. Just too human. Will you act as a human again, Clare? Or are you still not going to listen?” Clare’s lips were folded back like a mask, her tears were dumb. Somewhere, she was listening for a little girl that had never been able to scream. A thing that was not unyielding slipped through Miria’s eyes.

 “Clare? You don’t yield, I’m leaving you here. I don’t even want to say it, but it’s needful. All I did for Deneve, for poor Tabitha, was what was needful; I never even tried to do anything else.” Her voice was low, clear as iron, but not quite directed to any one person present, “Cynthia, Queenie Hilda, Clare...I could fight, but I can’t save you. Won’t you come back?”   

 Helen looked up at the white faces gathered in the ruins, above the courtyard where Miria was standing. The Phatom was black with dust and smoke, lost to triumph or any joy. Every Warrior left alive was watching, and all of them feared her. Galatea shifted her grip on her sword.

 Miria. To this warrior, you were only a wall to overcome–but my wall, alone. Now you’ve taken everything. I can’t feel love or pain, in this silence. Just the fight...wounds don’t end it, the girl crying inside doesn’t make it stop. It’ll end me. The prey creature who had life from Teresa and burnt it pathetically away, in weakness and pain.  

 No. From the first time I fought Miria, I could feel something in me. Moving in the silence, fighting for my life...


 

 

*    *     *

“Clare. You’ve grown so pretty.”

“No. Teresa. I’m not–”

“It’s okay. You cleared your soul; you found mine. You still want to go on. It’s like Yoki synch. Your human soul–this living soul you took in with my flesh. It’s been so long, Clare–”

“Yes! But I can’t; I’m blind and dumb, I could never reach you–”

“But you’re going to try, and I am too. And remember the first time you saw me–your first fight with Miria? Joining your soul to another was what you practiced.” 

*    *    *

   Clare’s eyes opened; raising an empty hand, she stood up. Her face was serene, without surrender. Miria sighed once, and vanished.

  The kick knocked her head back onto a pillar. Clare’s hand had barely cut itself grasping the end of her sword, as her other leg swept Miria’s arms away. With her last Phantom step, Miria had snatched up Clare’s sword; they faced each other with swords in one hand.

  “This is your soul isn’t it?” Clare raised Miria’s weapon, “I know you have mine.”

  “Heavy, isn’t it?” In the dignity of her gathered strength, Miria grinned through hard breath, “Won’t you finish this now?”

  Clare’s smile was not so knowing as Teresa’s, but not so faint; something warm was behind her eyes.

  “Thank you for this, Miria.”
